title: Bardhaman Dakshin
text:
Bardhaman Dakshin (Vidhan Sabha constituency) (earlier called Burdwan South) is an <a href="Vidhan%20Sabha">assembly</a> constituency in <a href="Purba%20Bardhaman%20district">Purba Bardhaman district</a> in the <a href="India">India</a>n <a href="States%20and%20territories%20of%20India">state</a> of <a href="West%20Bengal">West Bengal</a>.
Overview.
Bardhaman had two state assembly seats – Burdwan North and Burdwan South, both of which were earlier part of <a href="Burdwan%20%28Lok%20Sabha%20constituency%29">Burdwan (Lok Sabha constituency)</a>.
As per order of the Delimitation Committee, the Brdhaman assembly constituencies were renamed Bardhaman Dakshin and Bardhaman Uttar. No. 260 Bardhaman Dakshin (Vidhan Sabha constituency) covers <a href="Bardhaman">Bardhaman</a> municipality. No. 266 <a href="Bardhaman%20Uttar%20%28Vidhan%20Sabha%20constituency%29">Bardhaman Uttar (Vidhan Sabha constituency)</a> (SC) assembly seat covers <a href="Burdwan%20II%20%28community%20development%20block%29">Burdwan II</a> community development block and Belkash, Bandul I, Rayan I, Rayan II, Saraitikar, Baghar I and Baghar II gram panchayats of <a href="Burdwan%20I%20%28community%20development%20block%29">Burdwan I</a> community development block. Both Bardhaman Dakshin and Bardhaman Uttar assembly segments are part of No. 39 <a href="Bardhaman-Durgapur%20%28Lok%20Sabha%20constituency%29">Bardhaman-Durgapur (Lok Sabha constituency)</a>.
The West Bengal political scenario has changed dramatically over the years. In the early years after independence it was a scene of fluctuating fortunes between the Congress and the Left wing parties, till the latter captured power in the late seventies. The <a href="United%20News%20of%20India">United News of India</a> in a candid analysis says, “The green surge swept Bengal to demolish the red bastion in 2011 Assembly elections… Moreover, as the Left still remained cornered in state politics, their neutralised voters are increasingly migrating to the BJP for a viable alternative.”
Election results.
2021.
 
Bardhaman Dakshin constituency 2011.
In the 2011 elections, Rabiranjan Chattopadhyay of Trinamool Congress defeated his nearest rival Nirupam Sen of CPI(M).
Burdwan South constituency 1967-2006.
Nirupam Sen of <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20India%20%28Marxist%29">CPI (M)</a> won the Burdwan South assembly seat in <a href="2006%20West%20Bengal%20state%20assembly%20election">2006</a> and 2001 state assembly elections defeating his nearest rivals Samir Kumar Roy and Paresh Chandra Sarkar (both of <a href="All%20India%20Trinamool%20Congress">Trinamool Congress</a>) in the respective years. Contests in most years were multi cornered but only winners and runners are being mentioned. In 1996 and 1991, Shyamaprosad Bose of CPI (M) defeated Sadhan Kumar Ghosh and Shyamadas Banerjee (both of <a href="Indian%20National%20Congress">Congress)</a> in respective years. In 1987, Nirupam Sen of CPI (M) defeated Pradip Bhattacharya of Congress. In 1982 and 1977, Kaustav Roy of CPI (M) defeated Shyamadas Banerjee and Pradip Bhattacharya (both of Congress) in the respective years. Pradip Bhattacharya of Congress won the seat in 1972. <a href="Benoy%20Choudhury">Benoy Choudhury</a> of CPI (M) won the seat in 1971 and 1969. S.B.Chowdhury of Congress won the seat in 1967. Prior to that there was a single Bardhaman seat.
Burdwan constituency 1951-1962.
Radharani Mahtab of Congress won the Burdwan seat in <a href="1962%20West%20Bengal%20state%20assembly%20election">1962</a>. Benoy Choudhuri representing <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20India">CPI</a> won the seat in <a href="1957%20West%20Bengal%20state%20assembly%20election">1957</a> and <a href="1952%20West%20Bengal%20state%20assembly%20election">1951</a>.
